qas.question: When did the Larsen-B ice shelf collapse?
What Antarctic ice shelf collapsed in 2008?
When did the most widespread melting of ice occur?
How large was the ice chunk that melted and refroze?
How high could the temperatures have risen to cause the melting?
What happened to the B-larsen ice shelf in 2002?
When did 570 sq mi of ice from the Wilkins Ice Shelf collapse?
Where did 15,000 sq mi of ice remain?

plausible_answers.text: ice from the Wilkins Ice Shelf

qas.question: What remaining ice collapsed on 9 April 2005?

context: In <a0_0>2002<a0_0/> the Antarctic Peninsula's Larsen-B ice shelf <b5_0>collapsed<b5_0/>. <b6_0>Between 28 February and 8 March 2008<b6_0/>, about 570 km2 (220 sq mi) of <b8_0>ice from the <a1_0><b7_0>Wilkins Ice Shelf<b8_0/><b7_0/><a1_0/> on the southwest part of the peninsula collapsed, putting the remaining 15,000 km2 (5,800 sq mi) of the ice shelf at risk. The ice was being held back by a "thread" of ice about 6 km (4 mi) wide, prior to its collapse on 5 April 2009. According to NASA, the most widespread Antarctic surface melting of the past 30 years occurred in <a2_0>2005<a2_0/>, when an area of ice comparable in size to <a3_0>California<a3_0/> briefly melted and refroze; this may have resulted from temperatures rising to as high as <a4_0>5 °C<a4_0/> (41 °F).
